{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Peter Benchley | image = Peter Benchley.jpg | caption = Benchley being interviewed about ''Jaws'' in "A Look Inside Jaws", produced by Laurent Bouzereau. | birth_name = Peter Bradford Benchley | birth_date = {{birth date|1940|5|8}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2006|2|11|1940|5|8}} | death_place = [[Princeton, New Jersey]], U.S. | occupation = Author, screenwriter and ocean activist | years_active = 1967–2006 | spouse = {{marriage|Winifred "Wendy" Wesson|1964}} | parents = Marjorie Bradford
[[Nathaniel Benchley]] | relatives = [[Robert Benchley]] (grandfather)
[[Nat Benchley]] (brother) | website = [http://www.peterbenchley.com/ www.peterbenchley.com] }} '''Peter Bradford Benchley''' (May 8, 1940 – February 11, 2006) was an American author, screenwriter, and ocean activist. He is known for the bestselling novel ''[[Jaws (novel)|Jaws]]'' and co-wrote its subsequent [[Jaws (film)|film adaptation]] with [[Carl Gottlieb]]. Several more of his works were also adapted for both cinema and television, including ''[[The Deep (1977 film)|The Deep]]'', ''[[The Island (Benchley novel)|The Island]]'', ''[[Beast (Benchley novel)|Beast]]'', and ''[[White Shark (novel)|White Shark]]''. Later in life, Benchley came to regret writing such sensationalist literature about [[shark]]s, which he felt encouraged excessive fear and unnecessary culls of such an important predator in ocean [[ecosystem]]s and became an outspoken advocate for [[marine conservation]]. == Early life == Benchley was the son of Marjorie (née Bradford) and author [[Nathaniel Benchley]] and grandson of [[Algonquin Round Table]] founder [[Robert Benchley]]. His younger brother, [[Nat Benchley]], is a writer and actor. Peter Benchley was an alumnus of the [[Allen-Stevenson School]], [[Phillips Exeter Academy]] and [[Harvard University]]. After graduating from college in 1961, Benchley travelled around the world for a year. The experience was told in his first book, a travel memoir titled ''Time and a Ticket'', published by Houghton Mifflin in 1964. Following his return to America, Benchley spent six months reserve duty in the [[Marine Corps]], and then became a reporter for ''[[The Washington Post]]''. While dining at an inn in [[Nantucket]], Benchley met Winifred "Wendy" Wesson, whom he dated and then married the following year, 1964. By then Benchley was in New York, working as television editor for ''[[Newsweek]]''. In 1967 he became a speechwriter in the [[White House]] for President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]], and saw the birth of his daughter Tracy.{{cite news |url=http://www.towntopics.com/apr0208/stratton.php |title=After Nine Years on Borough Council, Wendy Benchley Sets New Agenda |last=Stratton |first=Jean |date=2 April 2008 |access-date=12 May 2018 |volume=62 |issue=14 |newspaper=[[Town Topics (newspaper)|Town Topics]] |publisher=Princeton's Weekly Community}} Once Johnson's term ended in 1969, the Benchleys moved out of Washington, and lived in various houses, including an island off [[Stonington, Connecticut]] where son Clayton was born in 1969. Benchley wanted to be near New York, and the family eventually got a house at [[Pennington, New Jersey]] in 1970. Since his home had no space for an office, Benchley rented a room above a furnace supply company.{{cite book |last=Benchley |first=Peter |date=4 June 2002 |title=Shark Life: True Stories About Sharks & the Sea |location=New York |publisher=[[Random House Publishing Group]] |isbn=0-307-54574-1 |pages=14–19 |chapter=2: Jaws |url=https://books.google.es/books?id=5CsIlp4GnrIC&pg=PT14 |chapter-url=https://books.google.es/books?id=5CsIlp4GnrIC&pg=PT12}} == ''Jaws'' == By 1971, Benchley was doing various freelance jobs in his struggle to support his wife and children. During this period, when Benchley would later declare he was "making one final attempt to stay alive as a writer", his literary agent arranged meetings with publishers. Benchley would frequently pitch two ideas, a non-fiction book about pirates, and a novel depicting a man-eating shark terrorizing a community. This idea had been developed by Benchley since he had read a news report of a fisherman catching a {{convert|4550|lb|kg}} [[great white shark]] off the coast of [[Long Island]] in 1964. The shark novel eventually attracted [[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]] editor [[Thomas Congdon]], who offered Benchley an advance of $1,000 leading to the novelist submitting the first 100 pages. Much of the work had to be rewritten as the publisher was not happy with the initial tone. Benchley worked by winter in his Pennington office, and in the summer in a converted chicken coop in the Wessons' farm in Stonington.{{cite news |last=Hawtree |first=Christopher |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2006/feb/14/guardianobituaries.obituaries |title=Peter Benchley |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=February 14, 2006 |access-date=February 15, 2011 |publisher=[[Guardian News and Media Limited]]}} The idea was inspired by the several great white sharks caught in the 1960s off Long Island and Block Island by the Montauk charterboat captain [[Frank Mundus]].{{cite book |last=Downie |first=Robert M. |title=Block Island History of Photography 1870–1960s |page=243 |volume=2 |year=2008 |oclc=428688552 |url=http://www.preservation.ri.gov/pdfs_zips_downloads/survey_pdfs/blockisland.pdf |format=PDF}} ''Jaws'' was published in 1974 and became a great success, staying on the bestseller list for 44 weeks. [[Steven Spielberg]], who would direct the film version of ''Jaws'', has said that he initially found many of the characters unsympathetic and wanted the shark to win.{{cite news |first=Stephen |last=Dowling |title=The book that spawned a monster |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/arts/3400291.stm |work=[[BBC News]] |date=February 1, 2004 |accessdate=January 1, 2009 |publisher=[[BBC]]}} Book critics such as [[Michael A. Rogers]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' shared the sentiment but the book struck a chord with readers. Benchley co-wrote the screenplay with [[Carl Gottlieb]] (along with the uncredited [[Howard Sackler]] and [[John Milius]], who provided the first draft of a monologue about the [[USS Indianapolis (CA-35)|USS ''Indianapolis'']]) for the Spielberg film released in 1975. Benchley made a [[cameo appearance]] as a news reporter on the beach. The film, starring [[Roy Scheider]], [[Robert Shaw (British actor)|Robert Shaw]], and [[Richard Dreyfuss]], was released in the summer season, traditionally considered to be the graveyard season for films. However, [[Universal Studios]] decided to break tradition by releasing the film with extensive television advertising. It eventually grossed over $470 million worldwide. [[George Lucas]] used a similar strategy in 1977 for ''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars]]'' which broke the box office records set by ''Jaws'', and hence the summer [[Blockbuster (entertainment)|blockbuster]] was born.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/film/1653733.stm |title=Rise of the blockbuster |work=[[BBC News]] |date=November 16, 2001 |access-date=August 17, 2012 |publisher=[[BBC]]}} Benchley estimated that he earned enough from book sales, film rights and magazine/book club syndication to be able to work independently as a film writer for ten years.{{cite web |title=Peter Benchley |work=[[Contemporary Authors]] Online |location=Gale |year=2003}} == Subsequent career == His second novel, ''The Deep'', is about a honeymooning couple discovering two sunken treasures on the Bermuda reefs — 17th century Spanish gold and a fortune in World War II-era morphine — who are subsequently targeted by a drug syndicate. This 1976 novel is based on Benchley's chance meeting in [[Bermuda]] with diver Teddy Tucker while writing a story for ''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]''. Benchley co-wrote the screenplay for the 1977 film release, along with [[Tracy Keenan Wynn]] and an uncredited [[Tom Mankiewicz]]. Directed by [[Peter Yates]] and starring Robert Shaw, [[Nick Nolte]] and [[Jacqueline Bisset]], ''[[The Deep (1977 film)|The Deep]]'' was a box office success, and one of the top 10 highest-grossing films in the US in 1977, though its box office tally fell well short of ''[[Jaws (film)|Jaws]]''. ''The Island'', published in 1979, was a story of descendants of 17th-century [[Piracy|pirates]] who terrorize pleasure craft in the Caribbean, leading to the [[Bermuda Triangle]] mystery. Benchley again wrote the screenplay for the film adaptation. But the film version of ''[[The Island (1980 film)|The Island]]'', starring [[Michael Caine]] and co-starring [[David Warner (actor)|David Warner]], failed at the box office when released in 1980. During the 1980s, Benchley wrote three novels that did not sell as well as his previous works. However, ''Girl of the Sea of Cortez'', a fable influenced by [[John Steinbeck]] about man's complicated relationship with the sea, was his best-reviewed book and has attracted a considerable cult following since its publication.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} ''Sea of Cortez'' signposted Benchley's growing interest in ecological issues and anticipated his future role as an impassioned advocate of the importance of protecting the marine environment. ''Q Clearance'', published in 1986, was written from his experience as a staffer in the [[Lyndon B. Johnson|Johnson]] [[White House]]. ''Rummies'' (also known as ''Lush''), which appeared in 1989, is a semi-autobiographical work, loosely inspired by the Benchley family's history of alcohol abuse. While the first half of the novel is a relatively straightforward account of a suburbanite's descent into alcoholic hell, the second part, which takes place at a New Mexico substance abuse clinic, is written as a thriller. He returned to nautical themes in 1991's ''[[Beast (Benchley novel)|Beast]]'' written about a [[giant squid]] threatening Bermuda. ''Beast'' was brought to the small screen as a made-for-television film in 1996, under the title ''[[The Beast (1996 film)|The Beast]]''. His next novel, ''[[White Shark (novel)|White Shark]]'', was published in 1994. The story of a Nazi-created genetically engineered shark/human hybrid, it failed to achieve popular or critical success. It was also turned into a made-for-television film titled ''Creature'', with [[Christopher Lehmann-Haupt]] of the ''New York Times'' saying it "looks more like [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] than any fish". Also in 1994, Benchley became the first person to host Discovery Channel's [[Shark Week]]. In 1999, the television show ''[[Amazon (1999 TV series)|Peter Benchley's Amazon]]'' was created, about a group of plane crash survivors in the middle of a vast jungle. In the last decade of his career, Benchley wrote non-fiction works about the sea and about sharks advocating their conservation. Among these was his book entitled ''Shark Trouble'',{{cite news |title=Peter Benchley's 'Shark Trouble' |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/peter-benchleys-shark-trouble/ |last=Wood |first=Robin |author-link=Robin Wood (critic) |date=28 June 2002 |access-date=12 May 2018 |work=[[CBS News]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive Inc.]]}} which illustrated how hype and news sensationalism can help undermine the public's need to understand marine ecosystems and the potential negative consequences as humans interact with it. This work, which had editions in 2001 and 2003, was written to help a post-''Jaws'' public to more fully understand "the sea in all its beauty, mystery and power."{{cite book |last=Benchley |first=Peter |title=Shark Trouble: True Stories and Lessons About the Sea |page=13 |publisher=[[Random House Publishing Group]] |date=4 June 2002 |isbn=9781588362070 |url=https://books.google.es/books?id=5CsIlp4GnrIC&pg=PT7}} It details the ways in which man seems to have become more of an aggressor in his relationship with sharks, acting out of ignorance and greed as several of the species become increasingly threatened by overfishing. Benchley was a member of the National Council of Environmental Defense and a spokesman for its Oceans Program: "[T]he shark in an updated ''Jaws'' could not be the villain; it would have to be written as the victim; for, worldwide, sharks are much more the oppressed than the oppressors."{{cite news |url=http://www.theroyalgazette.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060217/MIDOCEAN/102170132 |title=Make your company a world wide known name with us! |newspaper=[[The Royal Gazette (Bermuda)|The Royal Gazette]] |date=17 February 2006 |access-date=August 17, 2012 |last=Hodgson |first=Tim |author-link=Tim Hodgson |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060605170033/http://www.theroyalgazette.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060217/MIDOCEAN/102170132 |archive-date=5 June 2006}} He was also one of the founding board members of the Bermuda Underwater Exploration Institute (BUEI). Benchley died of [[pulmonary fibrosis]] in 2006.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/4707576.stm |title=Jaws author Peter Benchley dies |work=[[BBC News]] |date=February 13, 2006 |access-date=August 17, 2012 |publisher=[[BBC]]}} ==Legacy== In light of Peter Benchley's lifelong record of shark conservation and educating the public about sharks, the Peter Benchley Ocean Awards have been instituted by Wendy Benchley and David Helvarg as his legacy.{{cite web |title=About the Awards |website=Peter Benchley Ocean Awards |url=http://peterbenchleyoceanawards.org/awards |access-date=25 December 2015}} In 2015 researchers confirmed a new species of lanternshark had been found off the Pacific coast of South America, naming it ''[[Ninja lanternshark|Etmopterus benchleyi]]''. Lead researcher Vicki Vásquez noted the author's work in promoting ocean conservation, particlarly sharks, as motivation.{{Cite news|url=https://www.livescience.com/53219-ninja-lantern-shark.html|title=Forget the Flashlight: New Ninja Shark Species Lights up the Sea|work=Live Science|access-date=2018-11-15}}{{Cite journal|last=Vásquez|first=V.E.|last2=Ebert|first2=D.A.|last3=Long|first3=D.J.|date=|year=2015|orig-year=|editor-last=|others=|title=Etmopterus benchleyi n. sp., a new lanternshark (Squaliformes: Etmopteridae) from the central eastern Pacific Ocean|url=http://www.oceansciencefoundation.org/josf/josf17d.pdf|journal=Journal of the Ocean Science Foundation|volume=17|pages=43-45|doi=|doi-broken-date=|via=}} == Works == === Fiction === * ''[[Jaws (novel)|Jaws]]'' (1974) * ''[[The Deep (1977 film)|The Deep]]'' (1976) * ''[[The Island (Benchley novel)|The Island]]'' (1979) * ''The Girl of the Sea of Cortez'' (1982) * ''Q Clearance'' (1986) * ''[[Rummies]]'' (1989) * ''[[Beast (Benchley novel)|Beast]]'' (1991) * ''[[White Shark (novel)|White Shark]]'' (1994; republished as ''Creature'' in 1997) === Non-fiction === * ''Time and a Ticket'' (1964) * ''Life's Tempo on Nantucket'' (1970) * ''Ocean Planet: Writings and Images of the Sea'' (1994) * ''Shark Trouble: True Stories About Sharks and the Sea'' (2001) * ''Shark!: True Stories and Lessons from the Deep'' (2002) * ''Shark Life: True Stories About Sharks and the Sea'' (with Karen Wojtyla) (2005) === Film === * ''[[Jaws (film)|Jaws]]'', 1975 film adaptation; actor: Interviewer. * ''[[The Deep (1977 film)|The Deep]]'', 1977 film adaptation; actor: Mate (uncredited) * ''[[Jaws 2]]'', based on characters from ''Jaws'' * ''[[The Island (1980 film)|The Island]]'', 1980 film adaptation * ''[[Jaws 3-D]]'' (a.k.a. ''Jaws 3''), based on characters from ''Jaws'' * ''[[Jaws: The Revenge]]'', a fourth film based on characters from ''Jaws'' * ''[[Dolphin Cove (TV series)|Dolphin Cove]]'', 1989 TV series * ''[[The Beast (1996 film)|The Beast]]'', 1996 television film adaptation * ''[[Creature (1998 film)|Creature]]'', 1998 television film adaptation * ''[[Amazon (1999 TV series)|Amazon]]'', 1999 TV series * ''[[Mrs. Parker and the Vicious Circle]]'', 1994; actor: Frank Crowninshield == See also == {{Wikisource}} * [[Jersey Shore shark attacks of 1916]] * [[Publishers Weekly lists of bestselling novels in the United States]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080716061505/http://www.sharks.org/benchleyaward/index.htm Peter Benchley at the Shark Research Institute] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090212155127/http://www.namcnewswire.com/releases/content/view/928/2/ The Peter Benchley Shark Conservation Awards] * [http://www.sharkalliance.org/content.asp?did=1538 Shark Alliance] * [http://www.peterbenchley.com/ Official site] * {{IMDb name|1940|Peter Benchley}} * [http://www.theroyalgazette.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060217/MIDOCEAN/102170132 Peter Benchley: Rapture of The Deep] * [http://articles.latimes.com/2006/feb/13/local/me-benchley13 Peter Benchley: Shark Conservationist (''LA Times'')] {{Jaws movies}} {{Shark Week}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Benchley, Peter}} [[Category:1940 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:American nature writers]] [[Category:20th-century American novelists]] [[Category:20th-century American male writers]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Jaws (franchise)]] [[Category:Writers from New York City]] [[Category:United States Marine Corps reservists]] [[Category:People from Pennington, New Jersey]] [[Category:People from Stonington, Connecticut]] [[Category:Phillips Exeter Academy alumni]] [[Category:American male screenwriters]] [[Category:American male novelists]] [[Category:Deaths from pulmonary fibrosis]] [[Category:Novelists from New York (state)]] [[Category:20th-century American non-fiction writers]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Screenwriters from New York (state)]] [[Category:Screenwriters from New Jersey]] [[Category:Screenwriters from Connecticut]]

[[File:Hanuman fetches the herb-bearing mountain, in a print from the Ravi Varma Press, 1910's.jpg|thumb|Hanuman retrieves Sanjeevani by taking the entire mountain]] In [[Hindu mythology]], '''sanjeevani''' is a magical [[herbal medicine|herb]] which has the power to cure serious nervous system problems. It was believed that medicines prepared from this herb could revive situations where death is almost certain. The herb is mentioned in the [[Ramayana]] when [[Ravana]]'s son [[Indrajit]] (Meghnad) hurls a powerful weapon at [[Lakshmana]]. Lakshmana is badly wounded and is nearly killed by Indrajit. [[Hanuman]] was called upon to fetch this herb from the mount [[Dunagiri (mountain)|Dronagiri]] (Mahodaya) in the [[Himalayas]]. Upon reaching Dronagiri Parvat, Hanuman could not identify the herb and lifted the whole mountain and brought it to the battlefield.<ref name=search2009>{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/sci-tech/science/in-search-of-the-sanjeevani-plant-of-ramayana/article17925.ece |title=In search of the Sanjeevani plant of Ramayana |newspaper=The Hindu|date=11 September 2009|author=D. Balasubramaniam |accessdate= 29 July 2016}}</ref>
Several plants have been proposed as possible candidates for the sanjeevani plant, including: ''[[Selaginella bryopteris]]'', ''[[Dendrobium plicatile]]'' (synonym ''Desmotrichum fimbriatum''), ''[[Cressa cretica]]'', and others. A search of ancient texts at [[CSIR India|CSIR]] laboratories did not reveal any plant that can be definitively confirmed as sanjeevani. In certain texts it is written that sanjeevani glows in the dark.<ref>[http://www.telegraphindia.com/1050929/asp/nation/story_5297959.asp Telegraph India]</ref><ref>[http://www.currentscience.ac.in/Downloads/article_id_097_04_0484_0489_0.pdf ''In search of Sanjeevani'', Current Science, Vol. 97, No. 4, 25 August 2009 ]</ref>
The herb, believed in [[Ayurvedic]] medicine to have medicinal properties, has been searched for unsuccessfully for centuries, up to modern times.<ref name=search2009 /> The Himalayan state of [[Uttarakhand]] in northern India committed an initial 250m rupees (£2.8m) of state money to search for ''sanjeevani booti'' starting in August 2016. The search was focused on the [[Dronagiri]] range of the [[Himalayas]] near the Chinese border. The [[Ramayana]] mentions a mountain believed to refer to the Dronagiri range, where the magical herb is supposed to grow. Uttarakhand established a Department of Ayurveda, Yoga and Naturopathy, Unani, Siddha and Homoeopathy (Ayush) in November 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/28/indian-state-uttarakhand-hunts-mythical-glow-in-the-dark-plant |title=Indian state steps up hunt for mythical glow-in-the dark plant |newspaper=The Guardian |date=29 July 2016 |author=Agence France-Presse |accessdate= 29 July 2016}}</ref>

[[Image:Sarsen in Wiltshire.jpg|thumb|Sarsens in a garden in Wiltshire]] '''Sarsen''' stones are sandstone blocks found in quantity in the United Kingdom on [[Salisbury Plain]] and the [[Marlborough Downs]] in Wiltshire; in [[Kent]]; and in smaller quantities in [[Berkshire]], [[Essex]], [[Oxfordshire]], [[Dorset]] and [[Hampshire]]. They are the post-glacial<ref>[http://www.cityofwinchester.co.uk/history/html/sarsens.html Sarsen stones in Winchester] at a travel guide website for Winchester, Hampshire</ref> remains of a cap of [[Cenozoic]] [[silcrete]] that once covered much of southern England – a dense, hard rock created from [[sand]] bound by a [[silica]] cement, making it a kind of silicified sandstone. This is thought to have formed during [[Neogene]] to [[Quaternary]] [[weathering]] by the silicification of Upper [[Paleocene]] [[Lambeth Group]] sediments, resulting from acid leaching.<ref name="Stewart Ullyot">{{cite journal|last=Stewart Ullyot|first=J. |author2=Nash D.J. |author3=Whiteman C.A. |author4=Mortimore R.N.|year=2004|title=Distribution, petrology and mode of development of silcretes (sarsens and puddingstones) on the eastern South Downs, UK|journal=[[Earth Surface Processes and Landforms]]|volume=29|issue=12|doi=10.1002/esp.1136|bibcode = 2004ESPL...29.1509U }}</ref>
The word "sarsen" (pronunciation ['sa:sǝn]) is a shortening of "Saracen stone" which arose in the [[Wiltshire dialect]]. "[[Saracen]]" was a common name for [[Muslim]]s, and came by extension to be used for anything regarded as non-Christian, whether Muslim, pagan Celtic, or other.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Stevens|first1=Frank|title=Stonehenge|url=http://www.sarsen.org/2011_08_01_archive.html|website=www.sarsen.org|accessdate=4 September 2014}}</ref>
==Human uses== The builders of [[Stonehenge]] used these stones for the heelstone and sarsen circle uprights.<ref>Bruce Bedlam ''[http://www.stonehenge.tv/stones.html The stones of Stonehenge]''</ref> [[Avebury]]<ref>''[http://www.sacredsites.com/europe/england/avebury.html Stone ring of Avebury]'' at Places of Peace and Power website</ref> and many other [[megalith]]ic monuments in southern England are also built with sarsen stones.
Fire and in later times explosives were sometimes employed to break the stone into pieces of a suitable size for use in construction. Sarsen is not an ideal building material, however. [[William Stukeley]] wrote that sarsen is "always moist and dewy in winter which proves damp and unwholesome, and rots the furniture". In the case of [[Avebury]], the investors who backed a scheme to recycle the stone were bankrupted when the houses they built proved to be unsaleable and also prone to burning down. However, despite these problems, sarsen remained highly prized for its durability, being a favoured material for steps and [[Curb (road)|kerb]] stones.
==See also== * [[Hertfordshire puddingstone]] * [[Blowing Stone]] * [[Fyfield Down]] * [[Coronation Stone (Kingston upon Thames)]] * [[Ashdown House, Oxfordshire]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.megalithic.co.uk/modules.php?op=modload&name=a312&file=index&do=showpic&pid=3671 Photo of Sarsens on Fyfield Down, Wiltshire] * {{cite journal|last=King|first=N.E.|title=The Kennet Valley Sarsen Industry|journal=Wiltshire Archaeological and Natural History Magazine|date=1968|volume=63|pages=83-93|url=https://archive.org/details/wiltshirearchaeo6319wilt|accessdate=23 November 2016}} {{Commons category inline|Sarsen stones}}

{{italic title}} {{For|the stringed instrument sometimes referred to as a Scheitholz|Scheitholt}} [[File:Brennholzstapel aus Buchenholz.JPG|thumb|''Scheitholz'']] [[File:Obststiege-2.JPG|thumb|A small fruit crate made of wood and [[hardboard]]; in this case for strawberries]] '''''Scheitholz''''' is a German term for log sections that have been split lengthways with an [[axe]] or [[log splitter]] and that are primarily used for [[firewood]] or the manufacture of [[wood shingle]]s. The individual pieces of timber are called '''''Holzscheite''''' (obs.: ''Holzscheiter''), derived from the [[Old High German]] word ''scît'' = "piece". [[Wood gasification boiler|''Scheitholz'' boilers]] are used to burn quantities of ''Scheithölzer''. The expression ''"auf Scheitholz knien''" ("to kneel on ''scheitholz'') was a disciplinary measure used in times when [[corporal punishment in schools]] was still permitted.<ref>c.f. Anonymus: ''Hat der Schulmeister Brod? oder Ich bin Schulpatron'', Text eines Lustspiels, Prague and Leipzig by Caspar Widtmann 1786, [https://books.google.at/books?id=i9hJAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA72&lpg=PA72&dq=Scheitholzknien&source=bl&ots=kMmRw93Qtg&sig=kxyCP9bp9yag1tLbwfK3RxKW8yo&hl=de&sa=X&ei=z_VgUJLmB6Gp4gT1o4H4BA&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Scheitholzknien&f=false viewable online at Google Books].</ref>
Very thinly split timber is also called '''''Spanholz''''' or '''''Span''''', roughly the same as long-fibred [[Woodchips|wood chip]]s or [[wood shaving]]s, which may also be a waste by-product of the processes of [[planning]] or [[hewing]] wood. ''Span'' may also refer, however, to long-fibred slips or slices of wood especially of [[Populus|poplar]] and other softwoods, which are used to make wooden [[punnet]]s and fruit or vegetable [[crates]].
== See also == * ''[[Klafter]]'', an old unit of length or volume for ''Scheitholz'' * [[Fidibus]], a firelighter * [[Spanbaum]]

{{About|the Australian theme park|the unrelated U.S. theme park chain of a similar name|SeaWorld|other uses|Sea World (disambiguation){{!}}Sea World}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox amusement park | name = Sea World | image = [[File:Sea World logo.svg|250px|Sea World Logo]] | location = [[Southport, Queensland|Southport]] | location2 = [[Queensland]] | location3 = [[Australia]] | coordinates = {{coord|27.9559|S|153.4257|E|display=inline,title|region:AU-QLD_type:landmark}} | homepage = {{URL|www.seaworld.com.au}} | owner = [[Village Roadshow Theme Parks]] | opening_date = {{Start date and age|1971|10|30|df=yes}} | season = Year round | rides = 10 | coasters = 3 | water_rides = 1 }} '''Sea World''' is a [[marine mammal park]], [[oceanarium]], and [[theme park]] located on the [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]], [[Queensland]], [[Australia]]. It includes rides, animal exhibits and other attractions, and it promotes conservation through education and the rescue and rehabilitation of sick, injured or orphaned wildlife.<ref>[http://seaworld.com.au/research-and-rescue.aspx Sea World Research and Rescue]</ref> The park is commercially linked to [[Warner Bros. Movie World]] and [[Wet'n'Wild Gold Coast]] as part of the [[Village Roadshow Theme Parks|theme park division]] of [[Village Roadshow]].
==History== [[File:Seaworld Main Path.jpg|The main pathway through Sea World Australia.|thumb|right]] [[File:Sea world australia.jpg|The entrance to Sea World|thumb|right]] [[File:Sea World By Helicopter.JPG|View from the Sea World Helicopter.|thumb|right]]
===Park history=== Sea World was founded by Keith Williams in 1958. It was originally known as the Surfers Paradise Ski Gardens, which presented "water ski shows that combined comedy, aqua ballet and action". In 1971, the Surfers Paradise Ski Gardens moved to land on the Spit. Major dredging works were required to build the new ski lake. A year later, the Surfers Paradise Ski Gardens became known as Sea World with the introduction of dolphins, marine displays, a replica of the Endeavour, a swimming pool, licensed restaurant and gift shop. Extra additions over the next decade included the purchasing of competitor marine park, Marineland, and the transfer of animals and exhibits to Sea World as well as the addition of more shops and food outlets.<ref name="history">History and Development – Sea World. Retrieved from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Schools/Project-Information/History-and-Development.htm official website].</ref>
In 1984 Keith Williams sold the park to Pivot Leisure. Later in 1988 Pivot built the 400 room Sea World Nara Resort. In 1991 Pivot Leisure, Warner Bros. and Village Roadshow jointly developed and opened Warner Bros. Movie World, a Hollywood theme action park, at Oxenford on the Gold Coast. Also that year Pivot Purchased Wet n' Wild Water park located next to the site of Warner Bros. Movie World. In 1993, Warner Bros. and Village Roadshow jointly acquired Pivot Leisure's interest in Warner Bros. Movie World, Sea World and the adjoining Sea World Nara Resort.
===Attraction history=== {{See also|List of former Sea World attractions}} * In 1975, the Sea World train opened. "The train is a two-third scale replica of Queensland's famous number 6A10, which is now on display at the Queensland Railway Museum. The ride was designed and built by Sea World."<ref name="swtrain">Parkz Database: Sea World Train. Retrieved from the [http://www.parkz.com.au/parks/AU/Gold_Coast/Sea_World/ride/191-Sea-World-Train.html Parkz Database].</ref> * In 1978, the first major ride was added to Sea World. The [[Viking's Revenge Flume Ride]] opened.<ref name="history" /> This ride was custom-built at a cost of $350,000.<ref name="vrfr">Parkz Database: Viking’s Revenge Flume Ride. Retrieved from the [http://www.parkz.com.au/parks/AU/Gold_Coast/Sea_World/ride/16-Viking-s-Revenge-Flume-Ride.html Parkz Database].</ref> * In 1981, the park's first roller-coaster opened. Originally known as the [[Wild Wave Rollercoaster (Sea World)|Wild Wave Rollercoaster]], it was accompanied by the Pirate Ship and Carousel.<ref name="history"/> The Wild Wave Rollercoaster changed its name to the [[Thrillseeker (roller coaster)|Thrillseeker]] and closed in 2002.<ref name="thrillseeker">Parkz Database: Thrillseeker. Retrieved from the [http://www.parkz.com.au/parks/AU/Gold_Coast/Sea_World/ride/256-Thrillseeker.html Parkz Database].</ref> * In 1982, the Corkscrew rollercoaster opened.<ref name="history" /> The ride is an [[Arrow Dynamics]] Sitdown Looper and features three inversions.<ref name="corkscrew">Parkz Database: Corkscrew Rollercoaster. Retrieved from the [http://www.parkz.com.au/parks/AU/Gold_Coast/Sea_World/ride/251-Corkscrew-Rollercoaster.html Parkz Database].</ref> * In 1986, Australia's first monorail opened, the [[Sea World Monorail System]]. This ride features three stations throughout the park.<ref name="mono">Parkz Database: Sea World Monorail System. Retrieved from the [http://www.parkz.com.au/parks/AU/Gold_Coast/Sea_World/ride/31-Sea-World-Monorail-System.html Parkz Database].</ref> * In 1987, Sea World welcomed the Water Park and Lassiter’s Lost Mine ride.<ref name="history" /> Lassiter's Lost Mine ride was the second water ride for the park and was made in house.<ref name="lassiter">Parkz Database: Lassiter’s Lost Mine Ride. Retrieved from the [http://www.parkz.com.au/parks/AU/Gold_Coast/Sea_World/ride/120-Lassiter-s-Lost-Mine.html Parkz Database].</ref> * In 1989, the Sky High Skyway opened. It features a unique bird's eye view of the park.<ref name="skyway">Parkz Database: Sky High Skyway. Retrieved from the [http://www.parkz.com.au/parks/AU/Gold_Coast/Sea_World/ride/34-Sky-High-Skyway.html Parkz Database].</ref> * In 1993, Sea World is taken over jointly by Warner Bros. and Village Roadshow. * In 1994, [[Bermuda Triangle (Sea World)|Bermuda Triangle]] opened and replaced Lassiter's Lost Mine ride.<ref name="history" /> It used the same ride system but featured updated ride theming.<ref name="lassiter"/> Sea World opened the 3D theatre Sea Dream.<ref name="history"/> * In 1998, ''[[Pirates 4D|Pirates 3D Adventure]]'' debuted at the [[3-D film|3D theatre]]. The film uses "a series of special effects that enables the audience to feel part of the adventure".<ref name="history"/> * In 1999, [[Cartoon Network Cartoon Beach]] opened featuring five children's rides and an interactive water fountain.<ref name="history"/> * In 2003, Pirates in 3D was replaced with Planet SOS in 4-D. This film features an environmental message presenting the issues of global warming, ocean habitat destruction, and deforestation.<ref name="history"/> * In 2004, the park opened "[[Shark Bay (Sea World)|Shark Bay]]". This system of artificial lagoons allows [[shark]]s to be viewed from both above water and underwater. Sharks exhibited include large and potentially dangerous [[tiger shark]]s and [[bull shark]]s. * In 2005, the ski show received a makeover and became Waterski Wipeout. Also the water park got a makeover with the relocation of The Plunge from [[Wet'n'Wild Water World]].<ref name="history"/> * In 2006, the Sea World Eye was introduced for a limited time.<ref name="history"/> Swiss manufacturer CWA Constructions built the 60-metre high wheel which featured 42 air-conditioned gondolas.<ref name="sweye">Parkz Database: Sea World Eye. Retrieved from the [http://www.parkz.com.au/parks/AU/Gold_Coast/Sea_World/ride/211-Sea-World-Eye.html Parkz Database].</ref> * In 2007, Sea World introduced [[Sesame Street Beach]]. Sesame Street Beach replaced Cartoon Network Cartoon Beach with the addition of a new stage show and a new ride.<ref name="ssb">Sesame Street Beach – Sea World. Retrieved from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Rides/Sesame-Street-Beach.htm official website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090218230516/http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Rides/Sesame-Street-Beach.htm |date=18 February 2009 }}.</ref><ref name="parkzssb">Parkz Database: Sesame Street Beach. Retrieved from the [http://www.parkz.com.au/parks/AU/Gold_Coast/Sea_World/ride/23-Sesame-Street-Beach.html Parkz Database].</ref> * In 2008, [[Jet Rescue]] opened. Jet Rescue is a motorbike launch coaster made by [[Intamin]] which features jet-ski cars. It is themed to a sea-lion rescue.<ref name="jr">Parkz Database: Jet Rescue. Retrieved from the [http://www.parkz.com.au/parks/AU/Gold_Coast/Sea_World/ride/433-Jet-Rescue.html Parkz Database].</ref> Also '[[Ray Reef]]' opened featuring over 100 rays 'flying and gliding' under the water. It is Sea World's first new wildlife exhibit since 2004.<ref name="rayreef"/> * In 2009, Sea World updated and renewed several things. In early 2009, the Pirate Ship attraction closed and removed from the park. Waterski Wipeout performed its last show on 20 July 2009. Pirates Unleashed opened on Boxing Day as a replacement.<ref name="piratesunleashed">Wiped out by an act of piracy. Retrieved on 13.09.09 from the [http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2009/07/21/99795_gold-coast-news.html Gold Coast Bulletin].</ref> In September, Sea World announced the opening of Ocean Rescue, a new film for their theatre replacing Planet SOS in 4-D.<ref name="oceanrescue">Ocean Rescue | Sea World. Retrieved on 13.09.09 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Shows/Ocean-Rescue.htm official website].</ref><ref name="planetsos">Planet SOS in 4-D. Retrieved on 13.09.09 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Shows/Planet-SOS-in-4-D.htm official website].</ref> A new educational exhibit also opened in 2009 titled Shark Attack which replaced Dugong Discovery.<ref name="sharkattack">Shark Attack | Sea World. Retrieved on 24.09.09 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Marine-Attractions/Shark-Attack.htm official website].</ref> The Corkscrew rollercoaster was rethemed and renamed to become the Sea Viper. * In 2010, the park closed Shark Attack, the Sea World Aquarium, Ocean Rescue, [[Bermuda Triangle (Sea World)|Bermuda Triangle]] and part of the Water Park to construct new attractions. In September, ''[[Castaway Bay (Sea World)|Castaway Bay]]'' opened in former location of the water park. It is a children's area featuring ''Sky Fortress'' (a climbing structure), ''Sky Climb'' (a set of high ropes) and ''Battle Sails'' (a water battle). Also in September, Ocean Rescue was replaced by Happy Feet 3D Experience.<ref name="SundayMail 12.09.10">School Holiday Fun Guide (12 September 2010). ''The Sunday Mail''.</ref> In October, Sea World closed the Bermuda Triangle for routine maintenance before closing the ride permanently. Its replacement is expected to be open by late 2011.<ref name="BT RIP">{{cite web|last=Messenger|first=Jordan|title=Bermuda Triangle The Ride – RIP 1994 to 2010|url=http://gcguy.net/2010/11/22/bermuda-triangle-the-ride-rip-1994-to-2010/|publisher=GC Guy|accessdate=23 November 2010|date=22 November 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Attractions Maintenance – Sea World|url=http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Attractions-Maintenance.aspx|publisher=MyFun|accessdate=23 November 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uRvb9yAS?url=http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Attractions-Maintenance.aspx|archivedate=23 November 2010|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Attraction Maintenance|url=http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Attractions-Maintenance.aspx|publisher=MyFun|accessdate=3 December 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ugjCfAB8?url=http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Attractions-Maintenance.aspx|archivedate=3 December 2010|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=What is happening...|url=http://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?story_fbid=10150336287015582&id=283591200581|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=4 December 2010|date=3 December 2010}}</ref> Sea World also opened [[Penguin Encounter]], an Antarctic penguin exhibit where Shark Attack And Sea World Aquarium once stood on 26 December 2010.<ref name="GCB promocover"/><ref name="3 new attractions for Gold Coast theme parks">{{cite news|title=3 new attractions for Gold Coast theme parks|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2010/07/14/238251_tourism-news.html|accessdate=14 July |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100724042948/http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Attractions-Maintenance.htm |archivedate=24 July 2010 }}</ref> During the summer school holidays Sea World ran ''[[Jet Stunt Extreme]]'' as a temporary [[jet-ski]]-based [[stunt show]] located on the Sea World lake. It operated for a limited season until 23 January 2011. Sea World has noted that it could become a permanent addition depending on the overall success of the show.<ref name="Elder">{{cite news|last=Elder|first=Jessica|title=Sea World's jet-powered summer thrills|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2010/12/15/276865_gold-coast-theme-parks.html|accessdate=19 December 2010|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=15 December 2010}}</ref> * In 2011, Pirates Unleashed had its final performance on 20 July.<ref name="Pirates Unleashed ceased"/> [[Jet Stunt Extreme]] returned on 17 September 2011.<ref name="Jet Stunt returns"/> On 16 August 2011, Sea World announced a partnership with [[Nickelodeon]] which would see characters like [[SpongeBob SquarePants]] and [[Dora the Explorer]] appear in park shows from Christmas 2011.<ref name="Nick for Sea World">{{cite web|title=Nickelodeon|url=http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Visitor-Information/News/NICKELODEON%20COMES%20TO%20SEAWORLD.aspx|publisher=MyFun|accessdate=17 August 2011|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> ''SpongeBob ParadePants'' and ''Dora's Best Friends Adventure'' began on 17 December 2011.<ref name="Nick 2011 announce">{{cite news|last=Lacey|first=Michelle|title=Sea World to hold SpongeBob attraction|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2011/09/12/348761_gold-coast-theme-parks.html|accessdate=19 September 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62riqJme7?url=http://myfun.com.au/big3/|archivedate=1 November 2011|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Nick open">{{cite web|title=From today the...|url=http://www.facebook.com/seaworldgoldcoast/posts/10151048321505582|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=17 December 2011|author=Sea World|date=17 December 2011}}</ref> Towards the end of the year, [[Happy Feet 3-D Experience]] was replaced with [[SpongeBob SquarePants 3-D]]. Sesame Street Beach was replaced with [[Beach Break Bay]]. * In 2012, Sea World announced that they would be launching Dinosaur Island, an interactive dinosaur exhibit.<ref name="Dinosaur Island">{{cite web|title=Wall Photos|url=http://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151610286025582|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=4 May 2012|author=Sea World|date=4 May 2012}}</ref> The exhibit opened to the public on 16 June 2012.<ref name="Dinosaurs roaming Sea World">{{cite news|last=Ravn|first=Mackenzie|title=Dinosaurs roaming Sea World|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2012/06/14/424615_gold-coast-theme-parks.html|accessdate=23 August 2012|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=14 June 2012}}</ref> In December 2012, Sea World announced a "wild" attraction, set for a 2014 opening.<ref name="2014 attraction">{{cite web|title=Timeline Photos|url=http://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10152340857820582&set=a.10150305642055582.563523.283591200581|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=21 December 2012|author=Sea World|date=18 December 2012}}</ref> Although the attraction was initially promoted in-park and construction began,<ref name="The Parkz Update Nov12">{{cite web|last=Wilson|first=Richard|title=Sea World November 2012|url=http://www.parkz.com.au/update/2012/11/24/306-Sea_World_November_2012.html|work=The Parkz Update|publisher=Parkz|accessdate=22 July 2013|date=24 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="The Parkz Update June13">{{cite web|title=Sea World, June 2013|url=http://www.parkz.com.au/update/2013/06/11/314-Sea_World_June_2013.html|work=The Parkz Update|publisher=Parkz|accessdate=22 July 2013|date=11 June 2013}}</ref> Sea World has since removed all promotion of the attraction. A 2013 report in the Gold Coast Bulletin suggested the attraction would be a multimillion-dollar African jungle exhibit, including gorillas, hippos, and crocodiles.<ref name="Gorillas on theme at Sea World">{{cite news|last=Pierce|first=Jeremy|title=Gorillas on theme at Sea World|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2013/07/10/454340_gold-coast-news.html|accessdate=22 July 2013|newspaper=[[Gold Coast Bulletin]]|publisher=[[News Corp Australia]]|date=10 July 2013}}</ref> * In 2013, the park officially opened [[Seal Harbour]], a seal and sea lion exhibit, originally scheduled to open in December 2012.<ref name="Sea World to open new seal exhibit">{{cite news|last=Pierce|first=Jeremy|title=Sea World to open new seal exhibit|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2012/08/22/437108_gold-coast-theme-parks.html|accessdate=23 August 2012|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=22 August 2012}}</ref><ref name="Sea World exhibit gets seal of approval">{{cite news|last=Westthorp|first=Tanya|title=Sea World exhibit gets seal of approval|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2013/01/26/446144_gold-coast-news.html|accessdate=26 January 2013|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=26 January 2013}}</ref> A [[Jet pack#Externally-Powered High Density Propellant|water powered jet pack]] was also added to Jet Stunt Extreme.<ref name="Sea World launches extreme new show">{{cite news|last=Stojceska|first=Milena|title=Sea World launches extreme new show|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2013/01/23/445913_gold-coast-lead-story.html|accessdate=26 January 2013|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=23 January 2013}}</ref> In December, Sea World opened ''[[Storm Coaster]]'', a [[Mack Rides]] [[Water Coaster (roller coaster)|Water Coaster]], replacing the former Bermuda Triangle ride.<ref name="Water coaster bound for Australia in 2013">{{cite web|first=Richard|last=Wilson|title=Water coaster bound for Australia in 2013|url=http://www.parkz.com.au/article/2012/07/16/297-Water_coaster_bound_for_Australia_in_2013.html|publisher=Parkz|accessdate=31 July 2012|date=16 July 2012}}</ref><ref name="2013 campaign">{{cite web|title=Wall Photos|url=http://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151961046490582|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=31 July 2012|author=Sea World|date=31 July 2012}}</ref><ref name="Water Coaster">{{Cite RCDB|coaster_name=unknown|location=Sea World|metric=m|rcdb_number=11059|accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref> * In 2014, [[Sea Viper (roller coaster)|Sea Viper]] and [[Dinosaur Island (Sea World)|Dinosaur Island]] were closed. * In 2015, Sky High Skyway was closed and Beach Break Bay was replaced with Nickelodeon Land. * In 2016, Viking's Revenge Flume Ride was closed permanently.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gcthemeparks.com.au/blog/2016/12/vikings-revenge-flume-ride-to-permanently-close/|title=Vikings Revenge Flume Ride to permanently close – Gold Coast Theme Parks|website=gcthemeparks.com.au|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref> * In 2017, ''Dora's Best Friends Adventure'' was replaced with ''Paw Patrol on Holiday''.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://seaworld.com.au/animals-rides-and-shows/family-entertainment/paw-patrol.aspx|title=PAW Patrol on Holiday|website=seaworld.com.au|language=en|access-date=2017-12-20}}</ref>
==The park==
===Rides and attractions=== [[File:Castaway Bay Battle Boats at Sea World.jpg|thumb|Battle Boats at Castaway Bay]] [[File:Sea World Jet Rescue (cropped).jpg|thumb|Jet Rescue]] * '''[[Storm Coaster]]''' is a [[Mack Rides]] [[Water Coaster (roller coaster)|Water Coaster]].<ref name=RCDB>{{Cite RCDB|coaster_name=unknown|location=Sea World|metric=m|rcdb_number=11059|accessdate=24 November 2012}}</ref> The ride is [[soft opened]] on 2 December 2013 as a replacement for the [[Bermuda Triangle (Sea World)|Bermuda Triangle]] which closed in 2010.<ref name="H/Y 2012">{{cite web|title=Results Commentary For The Half-Year Ended 31 December 2012|url=http://asx.com.au/asx/statistics/displayAnnouncement.do?display=pdf&idsId=01384272|publisher=Australian Securities Exchange|accessdate=20 March 2013|author=Village Roadshow Limited|pages=16|format=PDF|date=21 February 2013}}</ref><ref name="Maintenance Mar2013">{{cite web|title=Attractions Maintenance|url=http://seaworld.com.au/plan-your-day/attraction-maintenance.aspx|publisher=Sea World|accessdate=20 March 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FFm7kX7m?url=http://seaworld.com.au/plan-your-day/attraction-maintenance.aspx|archivedate=20 March 2013|year=2013|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * '''[[Beach Break Bay|Nickelodeon Land]]'''<ref name="Beach Break Bay">{{cite web|title=Attractions Maintenance|url=http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Attractions-Maintenance.aspx|publisher=MyFun|accessdate=25 January 2012|author=Sea World|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64x20JFAA?url=http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Attractions-Maintenance.aspx|archivedate=25 January 2012|date=25 January 2012|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> is a themed zone featuring several rides specifically designed for children. The area was originally themed to [[Cartoon Network]] when it opened in 1999 before being rethemed to [[Sesame Street]] in 2007. In late 2011, it was rethemed to have the generic theme of Beach Break Bay. The area features 6 attractions including the Carousel and Beach Ball Bounce. In 2015 it was refurbished into Nickelodeon Land adding a Zamperla roller coaster and 4 new rides. * '''[[Castaway Bay (Sea World)|Castaway Bay]]''' opened in September 2010. It is contains a new children's area featuring ''Sky Fortress'' (a climbing structure), ''Sky Climb'' (a set of high ropes) and ''Battle Boats'' (formerly Battle Sails, an interactive water battle). It is located at the northern half of the Water Park.<ref name="GCB promocover">[http://www.parkz.com.au/forums/index.php?act=attach&type=post&id=2824 Promotional Cover for the Gold Coast Bulletin] by Warner Village Theme Parks. Retrieved on 26.06.10 from Gold Coast Bulletin.</ref><ref name="3 new attractions for Gold Coast theme parks"/> * '''The Reef''' opened in December 2017. It is splash zone expansion to Castaway Bay with over 80 water canons, spouts and an array of oversized marine animal sculptures.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://seaworld.com.au/animals-rides-and-shows/rides/the-reef.aspx|title=Castaway Bay The Reef – NOW OPEN at Sea World|website=seaworld.com.au|language=en|access-date=2017-12-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.goldcoastbulletin.com.au/lifestyle/travel/first-look-at-sea-worlds-new-splash-attraction-reef-at-castaway-bay/news-story/aff2463e541bba843ff2fb744bb0cba6|title=First look at Sea World’s new attraction|access-date=2017-12-20|language=en}}</ref> * '''[[Jet Rescue]]''' is Sea World's only dry roller coaster. The ride is themed around the journey of a Sea World Rescue Team on a mission to save marine life. Riders board a [[jet ski]] and race at speeds of up to {{Convert|70|km/h|mph}} around a highly twisted and banked track.<ref name="jetrescue">Jet Rescue | Sea World. Retrieved 24 September 2009 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Rides/Jet-Rescue.htm official website].</ref> * '''[[Sea World Monorail System]]''' was the first monorail system in Australia. It allows guests to travel between three stations throughout the park.<ref name="monorail">Sea World Mono Rail | Sea World. Retrieved 24 September 2009 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Rides/Sea-World-Mono-Rail.htm official website].</ref>
===Shows=== [[File:Imagine at Sea World.jpg|thumb|Imagine]] * '''Paw Patrol on Holiday''' is a live stage show featuring Chase and Marshall from Paw Patrol at the Nickelodeon Stage. It began in December 2017.<ref name=":0" /> * '''Affinity''' is the latest incarnation of Sea World's dolphin show. The show features similar tricks to previous shows with only the storyline and music changing. The show is set in Dolphin Beach which is the largest sandy bottom lagoon ever built for dolphins containing five different pools and more than 17 million litres of water. Each show caters for 2,500 guests.<ref name="imaginesw">Imagine | Sea World. Retrieved 28 September 2009 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Shows/Imagine.htm official website].</ref> * '''[[Jet Stunt Extreme]]''' is a live [[jet-ski]]-based [[stunt show]] located on the Sea World lake. It previously operated for a limited season over the summer of 2010–2011. Due to the success of the show it replaced Pirates Unleashed and became a permanent addition from September 2011 onwards.<ref name="Elder"/><ref name="Pirates Unleashed ceased">{{cite web|title=Pirates Unleashed|url=http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/SeaWorld/Attractions/Shows/Pirates-Unleashed.aspx|publisher=MyFun|accessdate=17 August 2011|author=Sea World|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6113IbLnN?url=http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/SeaWorld/Attractions/Shows/Pirates-Unleashed.aspx|archivedate=17 August 2011|year=2011|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Jet Stunt returns">{{cite web|title=Jet Stunt Extreme|url=http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/SeaWorld/Attractions/Shows/Jet-Stunt-Extreme.aspx|publisher=MyFun|accessdate=17 August 2011|author=Sea World|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6116UgQnu?url=http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/SeaWorld/Attractions/Shows/Jet-Stunt-Extreme.aspx|archivedate=17 August 2011|year=2011|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * '''[[SpongeBob SquarePants 3-D]]''' is a [[3D film]] currently showing in the Sea World Theatre. * '''Seal Guardians''' is the latest incarnation of the sea lion presentation, which began showing twice daily in early 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://seaworld.com.au/animals-rides-and-shows/family-entertainment/seal-guardians-presentation.aspx|title=Seal Presentation at Sea World|website=seaworld.com.au|language=en|access-date=2017-12-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://paradisecountry.com.au/sitecore/content/ThemeParks/Home/new-attractions.aspx|title=Theme Parks Box Office {{!}} Buy Tickets online|website=paradisecountry.com.au|access-date=2017-12-20}}</ref> * '''Turtle Power''' is a live show shown on a stage adjacent to Nickelodeon Land featuring the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles characters.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://seaworld.com.au/animals-rides-and-shows/family-entertainment/tmnt-turtle-power.aspx|title=Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles – Turtle Power Live|website=seaworld.com.au|language=en|access-date=2017-12-20}}</ref> * '''Our World of the Dolphin''' is an educational presentation on Sea World's dolphins and conservation and rehabilitation efforts. This show takes place at the front dolphin pools of Sea World daily.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://seaworld.com.au/animals-rides-and-shows/family-entertainment/our-world-of-the-dolphin-presentation.aspx|title=Our World of the Dolphin Presentation at Sea World|website=seaworld.com.au|language=en|access-date=2017-12-20}}</ref>
===Marine attractions=== [[File:Penguin Point at Sea World.jpg|thumb|Penguin Point]] [[File:Polar Bear at Sea World.jpg|thumb|Polar Bear Shores]] * '''Dolphin Nursery Pool''' is part of Sea World's highly successful dolphin breeding program which has resulted in dolphin births. The exhibit allows guests to see young dolphins develop under the protective watch of their mothers.<ref name="nursery">Dolphin Nursery Pool | Sea World. Retrieved 30 September 2009 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Marine-Attractions/Dolphin-Nursery-Pool.htm official website].</ref> * '''[[Penguin Encounter]]''' is a {{Convert|96|m2|adj=on}} Antarctic penguin exhibit featuring a {{Convert|220|m3|cuft}} pool with under and above water viewing.<ref name="GCB promocover"/><ref name="3 new attractions for Gold Coast theme parks"/> * '''Penguin Point''' is an exhibit featuring [[little penguin]]s. Unlike Penguins on Parade, the previous penguin exhibit at Sea World, Penguin Point has a larger, more open style. It contains a variety of substrates including gravel, rock and grass as well as a large pool. The exhibit can house up to 60 penguins.<ref name="penguinpoint">Penguin Point | Sea World. Retrieved 30 September 2009 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Marine-Attractions/Penguin-Point.htm official website].</ref> * '''[[Polar Bear Shores]]''' is Australia's only polar bear exhibit. It was one of the most technologically advanced exhibits for polar bears when it opened in 2000. Guests can view the polar bears from three viewing platforms: ground level, underwater and above ground. {{As of|2017}} there are four [[polar bear]]s in Polar Bear Shores: Liya, Hudson, Nelson and Mishka.<ref name="polarbearshores">Polar Bear Shores | Sea World. Retrieved 30 September 2009 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Marine-Attractions/Polar-Bear-Shores.htm official website].</ref> * '''[[Ray Reef]]''' allows guests to meet, feed and learn about one of the ocean's most misunderstood inhabitants. The exhibit features over 100 rays.<ref name="rayreef">Ray Reef | Sea World. Retrieved 30 September 2009 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Marine-Attractions/Ray-Reef.htm official website].</ref> * '''Rescue Point Lighthouse''' showcases the achievements of Sea World's Research and Rescue Foundation.<ref name="lighthouse">Rescue Point Lighthouse | Sea World. Retrieved 30 September 2009 from official website: [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Marine-Attractions/Rescue-Point-Lighthouse.htm].</ref> * '''Seabird Rehabilitation Aviary''' is designed to house birds under care and rehabilitation. According to the official website, "many of the sea birds housed in this area will never return to the wild due to severe disabilities which have been caused mostly by mans’ ignorance and careless ways. For example, we have received pelicans that have had a broken wing from being caught in fishing line. Their wings have since been amputated. Those that recover from their injuries are free to leave at any time."<ref name="seabirdrehab">Seabird Rehabilitation Aviary | Sea World. Retrieved 28 September 2009 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Marine-Attractions/Seabird-Rehabilitation-Aviary.htm official website].</ref> * '''[[Seal Harbour]]''' is a seal and sea lion exhibit which opened in January 2013. The exhibit has the capacity to feature up to 20 animals including [[Australian sea lion]]s, [[California sea lion]]s, [[Arctocephalus forsteri|New Zealand fur seals]], and [[subantarctic fur seal]]s.<ref name="Sea World to open new seal exhibit"/><ref name="Sea World exhibit gets seal of approval" /> * '''[[Shark Bay (Sea World)|Shark Bay]]''' is the world's largest man-made lagoon system for sharks. The exhibit consists of four zones allowing for viewing and interaction. The zones include a touch pool, an inter-tidal zone, a reef lagoon and a shark lagoon. Four 10 x 3-metre windows allows all guests to see the sea life featured in these pools.<ref name="sharkbay">Shark Bay | Sea World. Retrieved on 30.09.09 from [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Marine-Attractions/Shark-Bay.htm official website].</ref>
===Upcharges=== [[File:Warner Sea World Aviation Eurocopter AS-350B-2 Ecureuil Vabre.jpg|thumb|A Sea World helicopter landing at the park's helipad.]] * '''Animal Adventures''': for an additional fee, guests can take part in Animal Adventures where they can swim with Sea World's marine life.<ref name="animaladventures">Get up close and personal with marine animals on your family holiday at Sea World | Sea World. Retrieved on 13.06.10 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Animal-Adventures.htm official website].</ref> * '''Sea World Books''' is Sea World's latest franchise. The franchise offers educational children's books about various marine animals.<ref name="books">Sea World Books | Sea World. Retrieved on 13.06.10 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Sea-World-Books.htm official website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100724052051/http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Sea-World-Books.htm |date=24 July 2010 }}.</ref> * '''Sea World Cruises''' and '''Sea World Whale Watch''' make use of Sea World's "luxurious cruiser". During the winter months (when whales are travelling up and down the Gold Coast), Sea World operates whale watching tours. For the rest of the year, Sea World takes guests on a ride around the calm canals of the Gold Coast.<ref name="cruises">Sea World Cruises | Sea World. Retrieved on 13.06.10 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Sea-World-Cruises.htm official website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722162916/http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Sea-World-Cruises.htm |date=22 July 2010 }}.</ref><ref name="whalewatch">Sea World Whale Watch | Sea World. Retrieved on 13.06.10 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Whale-Watch.htm official website].</ref> * '''Sea World Helicopters''' allow guests to choose between 5 different tours of the Gold Coast ranging from 5 minutes to 30 minutes. For a further additional charge, guests can purchase a souvenir DVD of their flight.<ref name="helicopters">Sea World Helicopters | Sea World. Retrieved on 13.06.10 from the [http://seaworld.myfun.com.au/Attractions/Sea-World-Helicopters.htm official website].</ref> * '''Sirens of the Sea Photography''' is available during the run of the ''Sirens of the Sea'' show in the 2017-2018 Summer school holiday season. This upcharge allows you to get up close and personal with the mermaids, and have photography taken with Sea World's mermaids 5 times a day after their show times.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://seaworld.com.au/animals-rides-and-shows/family-entertainment/mermaids.aspx|title=Sirens of the Sea at Sea World|website=seaworld.com.au|language=en|access-date=2017-12-20}}</ref>
==Sea World Resort and Water Park== As the name suggests, Sea World Resort and Water Park is an adjoining Resort and Water Park to Sea World. In 2008, the Sea World Water Park became part of the resort with regular park guests having to pay an additional fee to make use of the water park.<ref name="swrwp">Sea World Resort unveils new water park master plan. Retrieved on 13.06.10 from [http://mediacentre.myfun.com.au/press/press_details.cfm?pressid=210&location=13 MyFun Media Centre].</ref> In 2010, part of the Water Park was demolished to make way for ''Castaway Bay''.<ref name="GCB promocover"/><ref name="castaway construction">Castaway Bay Construction Aerial. Retrieved on 06.05.10 from [http://www.nearmap.com/?ll=-27.954662,153.424115&z=18&t=k&nmd=20100506 NearMap].</ref>
==Television== Television series filmed at Sea World include the Australian children's programmes ''[[Toasted TV]]'' (since early 2007), Camp Orange, ''[[H2O: Just Add Water|H<sub>2</sub>O: Just Add Water]]'', ''[[Dolphin Cove (TV series)|Dolphin Cove]]'' and ''[[Mako: Island of Secrets]]''. ''[[The Shak]]'' was originally set at Sea World before being moved to [[WhiteWater World]].<ref name="wwwshak">WhiteWater World – The SHAK. Retrieved 13 September 2009 from [http://whitewaterworld.com.au/content/www_2008_standard.asp?name=WWW_Shak WhiteWater World's official website].</ref>
